30#include <sys/cdefs.h>
31__KERNEL_RCSID(0, "$NetBSD: i915_gem_tiling.c,v 1.6 2018/08/27 06:25:06 riastradh Exp $");
32
33#include <linux/string.h>
34#include <linux/bitops.h>
35#include <drm/drmP.h>
36#include <drm/i915_drm.h>
37#include "i915_drv.h"
38
39/**
40 * DOC: buffer object tiling
41 *
42 * i915_gem_set_tiling() and i915_gem_get_tiling() is the userspace interface to
43 * declare fence register requirements.
44 *
45 * In principle GEM doesn't care at all about the internal data layout of an
46 * object, and hence it also doesn't care about tiling or swizzling. There's two
47 * exceptions:
48 *
49 * - For X and Y tiling the hardware provides detilers for CPU access, so called
50 * fences. Since there's only a limited amount of them the kernel must manage
51 * these, and therefore userspace must tell the kernel the object tiling if it
52 * wants to use fences for detiling.
53 * - On gen3 and gen4 platforms have a swizzling pattern for tiled objects which
54 * depends upon the physical page frame number. When swapping such objects the
55 * page frame number might change and the kernel must be able to fix this up
56 * and hence now the tiling. Note that on a subset of platforms with
57 * asymmetric memory channel population the swizzling pattern changes in an
58 * unknown way, and for those the kernel simply forbids swapping completely.
59 *
60 * Since neither of this applies for new tiling layouts on modern platforms like
61 * W, Ys and Yf tiling GEM only allows object tiling to be set to X or Y tiled.
62 * Anything else can be handled in userspace entirely without the kernel's
63 * invovlement.
64 */
65
66/* Check pitch constriants for all chips & tiling formats */
67static bool
68i915_tiling_ok(struct drm_device *dev, int stride, int size, int tiling_mode)
69{
70 int tile_width;
71
72 /* Linear is always fine */
73 if (tiling_mode == I915_TILING_NONE)
74 return true;
75
76 if (IS_GEN2(dev) ||
77 (tiling_mode == I915_TILING_Y && HAS_128_BYTE_Y_TILING(dev)))
78 tile_width = 128;
79 else
80 tile_width = 512;
81
82 /* check maximum stride & object size */
83 /* i965+ stores the end address of the gtt mapping in the fence
84 * reg, so dont bother to check the size */
85 if (INTEL_INFO(dev)->gen >= 7) {
86 if (stride / 128 > GEN7_FENCE_MAX_PITCH_VAL)
87 return false;
88 } else if (INTEL_INFO(dev)->gen >= 4) {
89 if (stride / 128 > I965_FENCE_MAX_PITCH_VAL)
90 return false;
91 } else {
92 if (stride > 8192)
93 return false;
94
95 if (IS_GEN3(dev)) {
96 if (size > I830_FENCE_MAX_SIZE_VAL << 20)
97 return false;
98 } else {
99 if (size > I830_FENCE_MAX_SIZE_VAL << 19)
100 return false;
101 }
102 }
103
104 if (stride < tile_width)
105 return false;
106
107 /* 965+ just needs multiples of tile width */
108 if (INTEL_INFO(dev)->gen >= 4) {
109 if (stride & (tile_width - 1))
110 return false;
111 return true;
112 }
113
114 /* Pre-965 needs power of two tile widths */
115 if (stride & (stride - 1))
116 return false;
117
118 return true;
119}
120
121/* Is the current GTT allocation valid for the change in tiling? */
122static bool
123i915_gem_object_fence_ok(struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj, int tiling_mode)
124{
125 u32 size;
126
127 if (tiling_mode == I915_TILING_NONE)
128 return true;
129
130 if (INTEL_INFO(obj->base.dev)->gen >= 4)
131 return true;
132
133 if (INTEL_INFO(obj->base.dev)->gen == 3) {
134 if (i915_gem_obj_ggtt_offset(obj) & ~I915_FENCE_START_MASK)
135 return false;
136 } else {
137 if (i915_gem_obj_ggtt_offset(obj) & ~I830_FENCE_START_MASK)
138 return false;
139 }
140
141 size = i915_gem_get_gtt_size(obj->base.dev, obj->base.size, tiling_mode);
142 if (i915_gem_obj_ggtt_size(obj) != size)
143 return false;
144
145 if (i915_gem_obj_ggtt_offset(obj) & (size - 1))
146 return false;
147
148 return true;
149}
150
151/**
152 * i915_gem_set_tiling - IOCTL handler to set tiling mode
153 * @dev: DRM device
154 * @data: data pointer for the ioctl
155 * @file: DRM file for the ioctl call
156 *
157 * Sets the tiling mode of an object, returning the required swizzling of
158 * bit 6 of addresses in the object.
159 *
160 * Called by the user via ioctl.
161 *
162 * Returns:
163 * Zero on success, negative errno on failure.
164 */
165int
166i915_gem_set_tiling(struct drm_device *dev, void *data,
167 struct drm_file *file)
168{
169 struct drm_i915_gem_set_tiling *args = data;
170 struct drm_i915_private *dev_priv = dev->dev_private;
171 struct drm_gem_object *gobj;
172 struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj;
173 int ret = 0;
174
175 gobj = drm_gem_object_lookup(dev, file, args->handle);
176 if (gobj == NULL)
177 return -ENOENT;
178 obj = to_intel_bo(gobj);
179
180 if (!i915_tiling_ok(dev,
181 args->stride, obj->base.size, args->tiling_mode)) {
182 drm_gem_object_unreference_unlocked(&obj->base);
183 return -EINVAL;
184 }
185
186 mutex_lock(&dev->struct_mutex);
187 if (obj->pin_display || obj->framebuffer_references) {
188 ret = -EBUSY;
189 goto err;
190 }
191
192 if (args->tiling_mode == I915_TILING_NONE) {
193 args->swizzle_mode = I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_NONE;
194 args->stride = 0;
195 } else {
196 if (args->tiling_mode == I915_TILING_X)
197 args->swizzle_mode = dev_priv->mm.bit_6_swizzle_x;
198 else
199 args->swizzle_mode = dev_priv->mm.bit_6_swizzle_y;
200
201 /* Hide bit 17 swizzling from the user. This prevents old Mesa
202 * from aborting the application on sw fallbacks to bit 17,
203 * and we use the pread/pwrite bit17 paths to swizzle for it.
204 * If there was a user that was relying on the swizzle
205 * information for drm_intel_bo_map()ed reads/writes this would
206 * break it, but we don't have any of those.
207 */
208 if (args->swizzle_mode == I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_9_17)
209 args->swizzle_mode = I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_9;
210 if (args->swizzle_mode == I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_9_10_17)
211 args->swizzle_mode = I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_9_10;
212
213 /* If we can't handle the swizzling, make it untiled. */
214 if (args->swizzle_mode == I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_UNKNOWN) {
215 args->tiling_mode = I915_TILING_NONE;
216 args->swizzle_mode = I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_NONE;
217 args->stride = 0;
218 }
219 }
220
221 if (args->tiling_mode != obj->tiling_mode ||
222 args->stride != obj->stride) {
223 /* We need to rebind the object if its current allocation
224 * no longer meets the alignment restrictions for its new
225 * tiling mode. Otherwise we can just leave it alone, but
226 * need to ensure that any fence register is updated before
227 * the next fenced (either through the GTT or by the BLT unit
228 * on older GPUs) access.
229 *
230 * After updating the tiling parameters, we then flag whether
231 * we need to update an associated fence register. Note this
232 * has to also include the unfenced register the GPU uses
233 * whilst executing a fenced command for an untiled object.
234 */
235 if (obj->map_and_fenceable &&
236 !i915_gem_object_fence_ok(obj, args->tiling_mode))
237 ret = i915_gem_object_ggtt_unbind(obj);
238
239 if (ret == 0) {
240 if (obj->pages &&
241 obj->madv == I915_MADV_WILLNEED &&
242 dev_priv->quirks & QUIRK_PIN_SWIZZLED_PAGES) {
243 if (args->tiling_mode == I915_TILING_NONE)
244 i915_gem_object_unpin_pages(obj);
245 if (obj->tiling_mode == I915_TILING_NONE)
246 i915_gem_object_pin_pages(obj);
247 }
248
249 obj->fence_dirty =
250 obj->last_fenced_req ||
251 obj->fence_reg != I915_FENCE_REG_NONE;
252
253 obj->tiling_mode = args->tiling_mode;
254 obj->stride = args->stride;
255
256 /* Force the fence to be reacquired for GTT access */
257 i915_gem_release_mmap(obj);
258 }
259 }
260 /* we have to maintain this existing ABI... */
261 args->stride = obj->stride;
262 args->tiling_mode = obj->tiling_mode;
263
264 /* Try to preallocate memory required to save swizzling on put-pages */
265 if (i915_gem_object_needs_bit17_swizzle(obj)) {
266 if (obj->bit_17 == NULL) {
267 obj->bit_17 = kcalloc(BITS_TO_LONGS(obj->base.size >> PAGE_SHIFT),
268 sizeof(long), GFP_KERNEL);
269 }
270 } else {
271 kfree(obj->bit_17);
272 obj->bit_17 = NULL;
273 }
274
275err:
276 drm_gem_object_unreference(&obj->base);
277 mutex_unlock(&dev->struct_mutex);
278
279 return ret;
280}
281
282/**
283 * i915_gem_get_tiling - IOCTL handler to get tiling mode
284 * @dev: DRM device
285 * @data: data pointer for the ioctl
286 * @file: DRM file for the ioctl call
287 *
288 * Returns the current tiling mode and required bit 6 swizzling for the object.
289 *
290 * Called by the user via ioctl.
291 *
292 * Returns:
293 * Zero on success, negative errno on failure.
294 */
295int
296i915_gem_get_tiling(struct drm_device *dev, void *data,
297 struct drm_file *file)
298{
299 struct drm_i915_gem_get_tiling *args = data;
300 struct drm_i915_private *dev_priv = dev->dev_private;
301 struct drm_gem_object *gobj;
302 struct drm_i915_gem_object *obj;
303
304 gobj = drm_gem_object_lookup(dev, file, args->handle);
305 if (gobj == NULL)
306 return -ENOENT;
307 obj = to_intel_bo(gobj);
308
309 mutex_lock(&dev->struct_mutex);
310
311 args->tiling_mode = obj->tiling_mode;
312 switch (obj->tiling_mode) {
313 case I915_TILING_X:
314 args->swizzle_mode = dev_priv->mm.bit_6_swizzle_x;
315 break;
316 case I915_TILING_Y:
317 args->swizzle_mode = dev_priv->mm.bit_6_swizzle_y;
318 break;
319 case I915_TILING_NONE:
320 args->swizzle_mode = I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_NONE;
321 break;
322 default:
323 DRM_ERROR("unknown tiling mode\n");
324 }
325
326 /* Hide bit 17 from the user -- see comment in i915_gem_set_tiling */
327 if (dev_priv->quirks & QUIRK_PIN_SWIZZLED_PAGES)
328 args->phys_swizzle_mode = I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_UNKNOWN;
329 else
330 args->phys_swizzle_mode = args->swizzle_mode;
331 if (args->swizzle_mode == I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_9_17)
332 args->swizzle_mode = I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_9;
333 if (args->swizzle_mode == I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_9_10_17)
334 args->swizzle_mode = I915_BIT_6_SWIZZLE_9_10;
335
336 drm_gem_object_unreference(&obj->base);
337 mutex_unlock(&dev->struct_mutex);
338
339 return 0;
340}
